newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine stocks rebound, aided by U.S., bonds.
newsitem.headline: Argentine stocks rebound, aided by U.S., bonds.

text.p: Argentine stocks rebounded Tuesday from a sharp slump a session earlier, supported by a rise on Wall Street and firmer Brady bonds.
The blue-chip MerVal index recovered 1.29 percent to close at 715.25 points after a dive of 4.47 percent Monday.
Traders said activity was choppy but after the gains by bonds and Wall Street in the wake of U.S. economic figures, the Argentine stock market followed suit.
At one stage in the session, the MerVal was down 0.53 percent but the market recovered to close at the day's highs.

Sergio Martinez, a stock trader, said the market was set to closely follow the U.S. market ahead of the release of key U.S. unemployment figures Friday, which will give a better indication of inflation pressures in the U.S. economy.
"The market has no alternative but to follow the U.S. markets," he said.
"The sellers did not come out today like in recent sessions. The key day will be Friday," said Miguel Daneri, an analyst at Boston Securities.
Trading volume fell to 17 million pesos from 19.9 million pesos Monday.
Of the 58 stocks traded this session, 22 advanced, 23 fell and 13 were unchanged.
The stock markets' general index rose 0.66 percent.
Among top performers this session were holding company Garovaglio which rose 4.68 percent, and oil company Astra which added 3.52 percent.
